sections.title: Introduction
sections.content:
Related articles

- List of applications/Other#Application launchers

dmenu is a fast and lightweight dynamic menu for X. It reads arbitrary text from stdin, and creates a menu with one item for each line. The user can then select an item, through the arrow keys or typing a part of the name, and the line is printed to stdout. dmenu_run is a wrapper that ships with the dmenu distribution that allows its use as an application launcher.

sections.title: Installation
sections.content:
Install the dmenu package, or dmenu-gitAUR for the development version.

Various patched variants exist which extend dmenu's default functionality.

You may run dmenu with:

```
$ dmenu_run
```

sections.title: Configuration
sections.content: Now, you will want to attach the dmenu_run command to a keystroke combination. This can be done either via your window manager or desktop environment configuration, or with a program like xbindkeys. See the Hotkeys article for more information.

sections.title: Displaying custom items
sections.content:
Custom items will be shown by separating them with a new line (\n) and piping them into dmenu. For example:

```
$ echo -e "first\nsecond\nthird" | dmenu
```

sections.title: Manually adding items
sections.content: dmenu will look for executables in the directories defined in your $PATH. For information on modifying your $PATH see environment variables.

sections.title: Fonts
sections.content:
dmenu can display fonts using XFT. This example will run dmenu using ttf-droid:

```
$ dmenu_run -fn 'Droid Sans Mono-9'
```

sections.title: Support for shell aliases
sections.content: dmenu does not support shell aliases. To have dmenu recognize your aliases, install the dmenu-recent-aliases-gitAUR package and run dmenu-recent-aliases. Your aliases must be in ~/.bash_aliases to be recognized by dmenu-recent-aliases.

sections.title: Support for history
sections.content: To sort commands by recency, download dmenu_run_history to your $PATH and use dmenu_run_history instead of dmenu_run.

sections.title: Taking input using dmenu
sections.content:
Inside a script (e.g. launched from a shortcut), getting user input is sometimes required. We can use dmenu for this, by passing it an EOF: the selection field will be empty and dmenu can take user input.

Since reading /dev/null will return an EOF, this can simply be done by the following command:

```
$ dmenu < /dev/null
```

sections.title: Embedding in current terminal
sections.content:
Dmenu can be embeded inside any window using the -w id option.

To embed it inside the currenctly active window (like for example the terminal it is being run from), use xdo to get its id:

```
$ echo hello | dmenu -w $(xdo id)
```

sections.title: No locale support
sections.content:
Running dmenu_run results in the following error message:

```
$ dmenu_run
```

```
no locale support
```

Make sure that the environment variable LANG is correctly set. See the following for more information: Locale#Troubleshooting

sections.title: Missing menu entries
sections.content:
If certain entries are missing from dmenu, the cache may be malformed. Delete it and restart dmenu.

```
$ rm ~/.dmenu_cache
$ rm ~/.cache/dmenu_run
```

Note that there will most likely be only one cache file, depending on if $XDG_CACHE_HOME is set. See the contents of /usr/bin/dmenu_run for more information.

sections.title: Environment variables
sections.content: Environment variables needed for applications should instead be added to /etc/environment.
